Birth control and other contraceptives are free in British Columbia, but the year-long pilot project is rolling out with some issues.  Six different contraceptives, including IUDs (intrauterine devices), hormone injections and the morning-after pill, were first made freely available at the beginning of April.  "April 1 was a weekend and when we returned on Monday, there were 350 telephone calls and requests from physicians for referrals for IUD insertion. So it was a big jump for us," Dr. Renee Hall, medical co-director of Willow Clinic in Vancouver, told CTV's Your Morning on Wednesday.  Hall says the surge in demand means backlogs of up to two months for an IUD appointment. Willow Clinic also inserts contraceptive implants like Nexplanon and provides medicated abortions.  "When you've chosen birth control, that is the method that fits your lifestyle and you're not able to get it, you're using something that isn't ideal for you," Hall said. "So your risk for unintended pregnancy is higher during that period of time, which is why we've always tried to keep the waitlist down below two weeks."  With a decrease in the number of physicians inserting IUDs also adding to wait times, Hall said a remuneration fee could incentivize more physicians and clinics to provide the service. Additional government support could also help, she said.  "Some of our specialty clinics (that) insert IUDs all day long, need to have some government subsidy. It's very expensive," Hall said.  Birth control care is a specialized practice within medicine, meaning not all clinics provide related services.  "It's not something that everyone wants to do, just like maternity care, there's always going to be a group who loves doing it," Hall said, warning that backlogs won‚Äôt disappear without changes.  "Until there are some changes with regard to the way that IUDs are remunerated or these specialty clinics are subsidized, it's going to continue," she said. "There isn't an end in sight."  To hear the full interview click the link at the top of this article.

The newborn was missing in the early hours of Wednesday, police said. (Representational)  A newborn went missing from a government hospital in Noida on Wednesday, with the police lodging an FIR and launching a search operation for the baby allegedly stolen by an unidentified woman.  According to officials, the incident took place at the ESI Hospital, under Sector 24 police station limits, in the early hours of Wednesday.  The parents of the child live in Khoda Colony, Ghaziabad and the woman was admitted to the ESI Hospital on Tuesday for delivery, a police spokesperson said.  "After delivery, the woman was shifted to the ward. Today, when the woman woke up in the morning, the child was not on her bed. Upon being informed about it, the local police reached the spot and began an inquiry," the police official said.  "The police then checked CCTV cameras of the hospital in which a woman was seen carrying the child. This happened around 4.30 am today," the official said Wednesday.  The parents of the newborn have submitted a complaint with the local police station. An FIR has been lodged on the basis of the complaint and investigation launched to search for the missing baby, the police said.  (Except for the headline, this story has not been edited by NDTV staff and is published from a syndicated feed.)

Kazi Nazrul Islam  The 124th birth anniversary of National Poet Kazi Nazrul Islam will be celebrated across the country today in a befitting manner.  Ministry of cultural affairs has taken elaborate programmes to mark the day at the national level. Different organisations and cultural bodies, including Dhaka University, have also taken programmes to celebrate the day amid various functions.  President Mohammed Shahbuddin and prime minister Sheikh Hasina issued separate messages paying rich tributes to the memory of National Poet Kazi Nazrul Islam.  This year‚Äôs theme of the day is ‚ÄòAgnibinar Shatabarsha: Bangabandhur Chetanai Shanitarup‚Äô.  The birth anniversary of the national poet will be celebrated in the poet‚Äôs memorable place Trishal in Mymensingh, Doulatpur in Cumilla, Tewta in Manikganj and Karpasdanga in Chuadanga and Chattogram.  The main programme of the birth anniversary will be held at Darirampur of Trishal in Mymensingh. The three-day programmes will jointly be organised by the cultural ministry and the local district administration. Deputy leader of the Jatiya Sangsad Matia Chowdhury will inaugurate the programme.  Bangladesh Television, Bangladesh Betar and private television channels will live telecast the inaugural ceremony and air special programmes and print media will bring out special supplements highlighting the birth anniversary of the national poet.  Bangla Academy will pay respect to the national poet by placing wreaths at his grave near Dhaka University mosque and Nazrul‚Äôs portrait at Nazrul Mancha on the academy premises at 8:00am today.  Dhaka University has taken programmes to mark the birth anniversary of the national poet. As part of the programmes, teachers-students and officials-employees of the university will assembly at the Aparajeo Bangla at 6:15am and then place wreaths at the grave of Nazrul Islam near the university mosque lead by vice-chancellor professor Md Akhtaruzzaman. A discussion will also be held there with the VC in the chair.  Kazi Nazrul Islam was born on the 11th Joishtha in Bengali calendar year 1306 in Churulia, near Asansol in the Burdwan district of West Bengal.  He was famous for his fiery poem Bidrohi (The Rebel) and his many melodious songs. He was a poet, lyricist, musician, revolutionary and philosopher.  The nation got inspirations from Nazrul‚Äôs poems and songs during the great Liberation War and all democratic movements and struggles.  There are 2,400 Nazrul songs, and together, they are known as Nazrul-Geeti or Nazrul Sangeet. He composed the songs, which he liked to tune himself.  Considering his impressive talent, Rabindranath Tagore dubbed him as Saraswati‚Äôs bor-putra (the gifted son of the Goddess of learning).  Kazi Nazrul Islam was the poet of rebellion against injustice and taboos. His nickname was Dhukhu Miah (Mr Sorrow). True to his name, Nazrul suffered a lot in his life.  His father died in 1910 while he was still at school and he became the breadwinner of the family working for a bakery company, Wahid‚Äôs, the most well known in north Bengal at that time.  Later, he resumed studies at Darirampur, Trishal, Mymensingh. But he left his studies to join the British Indian Army as a non-commissioned officer and was posted to Karachi. He left the army and settled in Kolkata, where he started publishing a fortnightly, Dhumketu (The Comet).  The magazine had a fiery tone and was critical of the British rule in India. He soon found himself in prison for publishing a poem written by him, ‚ÄòAnandomoir Agomone‚Äô (Advent of Goddess Durga-the Goddess of destruction of all evil).  In prison, he did not stop writing. He wrote, ‚ÄòRajbandir Jabanbandi‚Äô (Deposition of a political prisoner).  After a prolonged hunger strike, Nazrul was released from the prison. But throughout the 1920s, he found most of his work banned. After the death of his second son ‚Äì Kazi Bulbul ‚Äì the poet was sad. He wrote, ‚ÄòMy nightingale sleeps forever‚Äô.  Although known for his rabid criticism of imperialism, social and religious taboos, Nazrul also explored the themes of love, romance and devotion.  He also introduced a robust style that was very bold and innovative. His use of Persian and Arabic words in Bengali poetry also opened up new literary horizons. In the 1930s, the leading gramophone company of India, HMV, as a lyricist, employed him full-time.  Later, All-India Broadcasting Authority employed him. But his luck once again ran out and in 1942, he developed a rare neurological disorder that led to the loss of his voice and memory. Doctors in Vienna diagnosed it as Pick‚Äôs disease.  After independence, Nazrul was declared the national poet and he was brought to Dhaka from Kolkata by Bangladesh‚Äôs founding president Sheikh Mujibur Rahman and given a house at Dhanmondi. He died in 1976 and was buried beside the central mosque of Dhaka University.

At the top end of the age spectrum, the number of people over 100 increased by half, from more than 53,000 people to more than 80,000. The share of men living into old age also jumped. Buddy Lebman, a 98-year-old in the St. Louis area, said the key to longevity is good genes and staying active. He plays bridge twice a week, leads a discussion on current events at his retirement community, and is still involved with his synagogue and a school he helped found. Up until five years ago, he went on regular bicycle rides.

KHYBER: Residents of Landi Kotal tehsil here have claimed they‚Äôre being overcharged for death, birth and marriage certificates.  They told reporters that the recently-appointed secretaries of village and neighbourhood chairmen asked them Rs300 each for those certificates against the official rate of Rs100.  The applicants said local body secretaries received 60-90 applications for death, birth and marriage certificates daily but they didn‚Äôt maintain any record of the excess amount collected from them.  They added that only Rs100 was deposited for a certificate in the account of the local government department.  Village and neighbourhood council chairmen Haji Sher Afridi, Haji Khan Shinwari and Yad Wazir confirmed the assertion and insisted that relevant officials were also involved in the irregularity.  They said the elected council chairman had no legal authority to stop their secretaries from the unlawful practice or seek details of the collected amount.  The council chairmen said under the rules of business, the heads and secretaries of local bodies were supposed to open joint bank accounts for depositing collected amounts, but the newly-appointed council secretaries didn‚Äôt do so.  They claimed that money could be withdrawn from those bank accounts only after the formal consent of account holders.  A village and neighbourhood council secretary told Dawn that the people were charged Rs300 for urgent death, birth and marriage certificates each.  He said that out of the Rs150 charged for any certificate, Rs75 was deposited in the Nadra account under the rules, part of it in the local government‚Äôs account and the rest for daily expenditure of their offices.  Officials of the local government department at Khyber House promised an investigation into the matter and said that if any irregularity was detected, punitive action would be taken against the culpable people.  Published in Dawn, May 25th, 2023

Welcome to the world of astrology, where the alignment of stars and planets is believed to shape our lives. Have you ever considered the impact of the time you were born on your zodiac sign?  Astrology suggests that the exact moment of our birth, in conjunction with the celestial bodies' positions, influences our personalities, destinies, and interactions with the world. While multiple factors contribute to the interpretation of your astrological profile, the time of day you came into existence holds a specific significance. We will unravel the hidden complexities associated with being born at night, urging you to consider the extraordinary dimensions lying within your zodiac sign.  Prepare yourself for a journey that will shed light on the enigmatic bond between nocturnal hours and the vast realm of astrology. Discover how being born at night can infuse your zodiac sign with an intriguing aura, profound depth, and heightened intuition that may have gone unnoticed. Brace yourself as we embark on an exploration of the mysterious influence that unfolds when darkness cloaks your celestial identity.  The Significance of Birth Time  In the realm of astrology, the precise time of your birth holds great significance, as it plays a pivotal role in shaping your astrological profile. Understanding the impact of birth time allows for a more nuanced interpretation of your zodiac sign and offers valuable insights into various aspects of your life.  Zodiac Sign Determination  Your birth time determines your zodiac sign, which reflects your core identity and character traits. The zodiac is divided into twelve distinct signs, each associated with specific qualities and symbolized by a constellation. The position of the Sun at the moment of your birth determines your zodiac sign, setting the foundation for your astrological journey.  Ascendant or Rising Sign  In addition to your Sun sign, the time of your birth determines your Ascendant, also known as the Rising sign. The Ascendant represents the zodiac sign that was rising on the eastern horizon at the moment of your birth. It influences your outward appearance, first impressions, and the way you interact with the world. Understanding your Ascendant can provide valuable insights into your overall persona and how you present yourself to others.  Planetary Placements  The birth time plays a crucial role in determining the positions of the planets within your astrological chart. Each planet represents different aspects of life and carries its own unique energy. The placement of planets in specific zodiac signs and houses at the time of your birth influences various areas of your life, including personality traits, relationships, career, and spirituality. Analyzing these planetary placements provides a deeper understanding of your strengths, challenges, and potential life patterns.  Aspect Configurations  Astrological aspects refer to the geometric angles formed between planets in your birth chart. These aspects, such as conjunctions, squares, trines, and oppositions, reveal the dynamic relationships and interactions between celestial bodies. The aspects in your chart provide valuable insights into your personality, strengths, and areas of life where you may face challenges. The birth time is essential for accurately interpreting and understanding these aspect configurations.  Timing of Transits and Progressions  Your birth time acts as a reference point for tracking the movement of planets over time. Astrologers analyze planetary transits and progressions to assess the current and future influences on your life. Transits refer to the current positions of planets in relation to your natal chart, while progressions symbolize the symbolic advancement of your chart as you grow and evolve. Understanding the timing and impact of transits and progressions requires the precise birth time as a starting point.  By recognizing the significance of birth time in astrology, you gain a deeper understanding of the intricate nuances that shape your astrological profile. It enables a more comprehensive interpretation of your zodiac sign, Ascendant, planetary placements, aspect configurations, and the timing of astrological events. Embrace the hidden depths and intricate connections that unfold when exploring the impact of your birth time in astrology, and uncover the invaluable insights it provides for navigating your life's journey.  Night Birth and Its Impact  The cloak of night has long held an allure of mystery and enchantment. Being born during these nocturnal hours adds a unique dimension to your zodiac sign, influencing your characteristics in fascinating ways.  In this section, we will delve into the profound impact of night births on your astrological profile. From heightened intuition to an affinity for the mystical, prepare to unravel the captivating aspects that emerge when darkness begets your zodiac sign.  Enhanced Intuition  Born under the cover of night, individuals often exhibit heightened intuitive abilities. The quietude of the nocturnal hours fosters a deeper connection to the subconscious and unseen realms. Night-born individuals possess an intuitive edge, allowing them to tap into their inner wisdom and navigate life's complexities with heightened perceptiveness. Their intuitive insights guide them in making decisions and sensing the underlying currents of situations.  Mystery and Depth  The darkness of night often imbues individuals with an air of mystery and depth. Night births bestow an introspective nature, leading to a penchant for contemplation and a quest to unravel the mysteries of life and existence. These individuals possess a natural inclination towards philosophical and metaphysical topics, constantly seeking to uncover hidden meanings and delve into profound insights.  Emotional Sensitivity  Night-born individuals frequently exhibit heightened emotional sensitivity. The tranquility of the night allows for introspection and reflection, fostering a deep understanding of the human condition. Empathy and compassion flow naturally from their hearts, as they possess an innate ability to empathize with others' emotions. This emotional receptivity enables them to offer support and solace to those in need, acting as pillars of strength during challenging times.  Lunar Connection  The moon, often associated with the night sky, holds a special influence over those born during nocturnal hours. Night births intensify the connection to the moon's energy, amplifying emotional receptivity, intuition, and nurturing qualities. These individuals possess a unique ability to harness the ebb and flow of emotions, finding comfort in lunar cycles. The moon's phases and energy fluctuations become a source of inspiration, aiding in creative pursuits and personal relationships.  Affinity for the Occult  Night-born individuals often exhibit a natural affinity for the mystical and occult. Their inherent curiosity and receptivity to the unknown lead them to explore alternative belief systems, divination practices, and spiritual paths. The silence and stillness of the night offer a fertile ground for delving into practices such as astrology, tarot, meditation, or energy healing. Night births awaken a fascination with the hidden realms and the desire to uncover deeper truths.  ~  In the captivating realm of astrology, the time of day we are born adds an intriguing layer of depth to our astrological profiles. Throughout this article, we have explored the surprising impact of being born at night on our zodiac signs, unearthing hidden qualities and illuminating unique characteristics that arise under the nocturnal sky.  From the enhanced intuition that guides us through life's complexities to the enigmatic allure and depth that shape our personalities, being born at night leaves an indelible mark on our astrological identities. The tranquility of the night allows for introspection, fostering emotional sensitivity and a profound understanding of the human condition. Our affinity for the mystical and the occult awakens, as we embark on a quest to uncover hidden truths and embrace alternative belief systems.  The significance of birth time extends beyond determining our zodiac signs; it influences our Ascendant, planetary placements, and aspect configurations, providing a comprehensive understanding of our astrological journey. It serves as a reference point for analyzing the timing and impact of planetary transits and progressions, offering guidance and insights into future possibilities.  As we embrace the transformative influence of our birth time, whether it be during the luminous daylight or the enigmatic night, we embark on a journey of self-discovery. Understanding the intricate interplay between the cosmos and our individual lives allows us to navigate our paths with greater self-awareness, unlocking the hidden treasures within our astrological profiles.  So, regardless of whether you were born under the bright rays of the sun or the mystical shroud of night, let the wisdom of astrology inspire you. Embrace the unique qualities that arise from your birth time and harness them as tools for personal growth, introspection, and connecting with the mysterious forces that shape our existence. May your astrological journey be one of exploration, self-discovery, and a deeper understanding of the intricate tapestry of the universe that we all inhabit.

It's more important than ever to stay informed - Get the free CheshireLive newsletter direct to your inbox  A baby who seemed 'healthy' when born was quickly diagnosed with a neuromuscular disorder after a doctor picked up on a problem with his breathing.  Frank Lloyd, from Ellesmere Port, was whisked off for tests after the medic noticed he wasn't breathing as he should have been. He had appeared healthy when he was born at Arrowe Park Hospital on January 28 but then the doctor flagged up concerns for the tot.  And tests revealed Frank had been born with a genetic condition called Spinal Muscular Atrophy (SMA) Type One, which makes the muscles weaker causing movement problems. Frank's parents Frazer Lloyd and Leah Statham have had their "ups and downs" since their son's diagnosis, according to family friend Joe Fearnyough, but Frank has been an "inspiration to everyone", reports the Liverpool Echo.  READ MORE: These Cheshire hospitals announce face mask rule changes  Joe, who grew up with Frazer, said that Frank is a real fighter and has already defied the odds.  "They are just a lovely couple and I honestly can't describe how great they have been through all this. They always have a smile on their face and the way they have handled the diagnosis has been amazing," he added.  (Image: Joe Fearnyough)  "They got lucky really, when they had the baby he looked fine and when you see him you would not think he has anything wrong with him. A doctor came in to check on him and noticed straight away that his breathing was not right. If that doctor had not come in, baby Frank would not be here now."  Frank has SMA Type One which develops in babies less than six months old and is the most severe type. It is a genetic condition that makes the muscles weaker and causes problems with movement.  In the past, babies with type one rarely survived beyond the first few years of life. But in recent years outcomes have improved with early diagnosis and treatment. However, it is one of the most expensive treatments on the NHS.  (Image: Joe Fearnyough)  Joe, from Ellesmere Port, said: "Frank is so inspirational and is honestly the most amazing boy that I have ever met in my life. Nothing gets in his way and he just deals with everything that has happened to him.  "Doctors said he might never be able to move his arms and now he can, they said he won't be able to talk and he already has a little voice. He inspires me and I wanted to do something for him."  Joe along with his friends will be doing a series of challenges to raise money for Frank and his parents. The first will be the Three Peaks challenge on August 25. For the first time in 16 years, the Smithsonian‚Äôs National Zoo and Conservation Biology Institute (NZCBI) in Washington, D.C., is celebrating the birth of three meerkats. Keepers in the Small Mammal House reported for duty the morning of May 10 and observed that 5-year-old Sadie had given birth overnight. NZCBI had received a recommendation from the Association of Zoos and Aquariums‚Äô Species Survival Plan (SSP) to breed Sadie and the pups‚Äô 6-year-old father Frankie. These pups are the first offspring for Sadie; Frankie sired offspring previously at his former zoo. Meerkats live in groups called mobs that can include as many as 30 individuals, although the average mob size is around 10 to 15 individuals. Visitors can view NZCBI‚Äôs meerkat mob‚Äîwhich also includes Sadie‚Äôs sister, Stella‚Äîat the Small Mammal House.  In the wild, meerkat pups typically remain in an underground burrow for about three weeks. To encourage the meerkats to exhibit their natural burrowing behavior, a system of tubing‚Äîconcealed within rockwork‚Äîruns along the outskirts of their habitat in the Small Mammal House. At the end of the tunnel, a nest box offers visitors a view of the meerkats‚Äô underground sleeping chamber. The day Sadie gave birth, she surprised keepers by bringing her pups into the main exhibit space.  Animal care staff are leaving the mob to bond with and care for the pups without interference. They are closely monitoring the family and have observed Sadie nursing her offspring, which appear to be healthy and strong. Because keepers and veterinarians are not handling the pups, it may be some time before they can determine their sexes. Now 14 days old, the pups are starting to open their eyes and explore their habitat.  The SSP scientists determine which animals to breed by considering their genetic makeup, health and temperament, among other factors. Sisters Sadie and Stella came from the Brevard Zoo in Florida, and Frankie came from the Los Angeles Zoo in California. All three arrived at NZCBI in November 2022. Keepers describe all three meerkats as sociable, energetic and inquisitive. Frankie is laid-back and will take food gently from keepers‚Äô hands. Sadie and Stella are quite bold and readily approach keepers. Initial ‚Äúhowdy‚Äù introductions among the three adults last winter went well, and they bred soon after meeting.  Native to southern Africa, meerkats live in the dry open plains, savannas and grasslands in Botswana, Zimbabwe, Mozambique and South Africa. Adults rotate sentinel duty throughout the day, looking out for predators. The International Union for Conservation of Nature considers meerkats as least concern.  # # #  SI-179-2023

Jo Cameron  KEY HIGHLIGHTS Doctors were first alerted to her condition after she underwent a serious operation but needed no pain relief during her recovery, according to a BBC report.  Researchers at University College London (UCL) have found out how the mutation works at a molecular level, enabling Cameron to escape the experience of pain.  It is believed that the same biological mechanisms allow wounds to heal more rapidly than usual.  In the 2018 film 'Mard Ko Dard Nahi Hota', the protagonist Surya (played Abhimanyu Dassani) feels no pain due to a rare disorder named Congenital insensitivity to pain (CIP).  He suffers serious injuries, breaks several bones but doesn‚Äôt wince even for a second.  While the reel representation remains in the realm of fiction, a 75-year-old woman from the UK is the living embodiment of the rare condition.  Jo Cameron doesn't actually feel any pain in her body due to a rare genetic mutation.  Scientists have now uncovered how the rare condition allows her to live her life almost pain-free.  Doctors were first alerted to her condition after she underwent a serious operation but needed no pain relief during her recovery, according to a BBC report.  Researchers at University College London (UCL) have found out how the mutation works at a molecular level, enabling Cameron to escape the experience of pain. It is believed that the same biological mechanisms allow wounds to heal more rapidly than usual.  The experts have also said the study of the conditon, published in the journal Brain, could lead to the development of new treatments.  "By understanding precisely what is happening at a molecular level, we can start to understand the biology involved and that opens up possibilities for drug discovery that could one day have far-reaching positive impacts for patients," Prof James Cox, of UCL Medicine was quoted as saying by BBC.  "As scientists it is our duty to explore and I think these findings will have important implications for areas of research such as wound healing, depression and more," said Professor Cox‚Äôs colleague,Dr Andrei Okoroko.  The 75-year-old says she has a history of injuries and burning her arms in the oven. She only realises her skin is burning when she smells singed flesh, adds the BBC report.  "I have a history of cutting, bumping and burning myself time after time, but it wasn‚Äôt till my doctor told me that I should be in agony following a hip surgery that I realised all the ‚Äòclumsiness‚Äô over the years was because I don‚Äôt feel pain like most people do," Cameron wrote for Metro.co.uk  People who undergo surgeries have to rely on painkillers to keep their pain at bay. Cameron said she has never taken any pills for post-surgery pain.  She also didn't any pain relief when she had he first child at age 30.  On one occasion, she broke her jaw, lost two teeth and cut her lip after tripping on a kerb, but felt no pain.  "I broke my jaw, lost two teeth, cut my lip and was badly bruised. I felt the swelling but nothing else," she said.

Jessie J wastes no time basking in the joys of motherhood and gushing about her little one every chance she gets.  The new mother who once suffered a miscarriage has been on cloud nine since the onset of her pregnancy, and on Friday, May 19, she proudly announced the birth of her first child.  About ten days following childbirth, she tells the world about her baby‚Äôs physical features while keeping him a secret.  Jessie J Hints At Her Newborn Son‚Äôs Impressive Physical Features  The English songwriter has some exciting news about her newborn, and she took to her Instagram Story to share them, revealing the little one had already outgrown his clothes.  She shared a photo of several onesies flatly laid atop each other, including a red and white one with heart patterns and a black and white piece. Jessie then attached a note touching on her child‚Äôs speedy growth and needing new clothes less than ten days after she birthed him.  ‚ÄúNot even ten days old, and I am already doing a wardrobe clear out,‚Äù she wrote. ‚ÄúMy boy came out LONG. I LOVE these, @fredandnoah.‚Äù  The 34-year-old added that although her son grew, his limbs developed faster, and he chose the day not to fit into any of his clothes. ‚ÄúHis arms and legs and feet said NOT TODAY, Mum. Pass me Dad‚Äôs shoes ‚Äì I‚Äôm going for a walk,‚Äù she jokingly concluded.  Fans may recall that over the weekend, ‚ÄúThe Voice UK‚Äù judge spread the fantastic news of her son‚Äôs safe delivery one week after it happened. She wrote in an Instagram Story statement,  ‚ÄúA week ago, my whole life changed. My son entered this world, and my heart grew twice the size. The feeling is indescribable. I am flying in love.‚Äù  She added a few more words of endearment for the tot, calling him ‚Äúmagic‚Äù and ‚Äúall my dreams come true.‚Äù The ‚ÄúNobody‚Äôs Perfect‚Äù singer further expressed, ‚ÄúHe is my whole [world]. He and I are both doing great. I am soaking up every second and still can‚Äôt believe he is real, here and mine. I am so grateful. Phew.‚Äù  She then rounded up with an appreciation for everyone who had been with her, loved, and supported her throughout her pregnancy journey. Jessie revealed her pregnancy to her followers for the first time in January with a heartwarming clip and noted conveying her happiness and terror to ‚Äúfinally‚Äù drop the news.  She pleaded with social media users to ‚Äúplease be gentle with‚Äù her before writing, ‚ÄúHonestly, ya girl just wants to ugly cry in public in a catsuit, eating a chocolate-covered pickle with no questions asked.‚Äù  Alongside the sweet message, she uploaded a video montage of her positive pregnancy test, images showing off her baby bump, and a video of her ultrasound appointment. In no time, she received so much support from many worldwide, including celebrity mothers like Kehlani and Gabrielle Union, who congratulated her.  In Kehlani‚Äôs words, ‚ÄúAll that patience, you did it,‚Äù while Union exclaimed, ‚ÄúYessssssss!!!! I‚Äôm so happy for youuuuuuu!‚Äù A remark from pop icon Katy Perry was also seen in the comments section, and it read, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm so happy for you, sending you all the momma love.‚Äù  The ‚ÄòDo It Like a Dude‚Äô Singer Revealed Her Baby Daddy Prepared For Fatherhood By Reading  Several days before giving birth to a bouncing baby boy, Jessie flaunted how her baby daddy, Chanan Safir Colman, geared up for fatherhood.  As The Blast reported, she posted a picture of a book guide Colman seemed to have been reading, which was titled ‚ÄúTHE EXPECTANT DAD SURVIVAL GUIDE. EVERYTHING YOU NEED TO KNOW.‚Äù  Reading up on details and guidelines about fatherhood was not the only way he showed support for his partner, as he was also captured being hands-on in an ensuing Story post.  As seen in the photo, he eased the muscles of the mother of his child by giving her an enjoyable massage. Jessie‚Äôs enlarged midsection was displayed as she rocked a cropped white sports bra and Nike socks.  In addition, viewers were undoubtedly drawn to the enormous tattoo on her midsection as she lay sideways on a bed with a pillow propped between her legs.

Advocates of stronger regulation of artificial intelligence have a long list of concerns and possible dangers backing up their argument, from short-term threats such as spreading believable misinformation to more existential far-off risks of superintelligent A.I. taking over humanity (or ‚Äúgoing Terminator,‚Äù in Elon Musk‚Äôs words). A more medium-term fear is that A.I. will be one of the biggest job disrupters in recent history, with Goldman Sachs calculating in March the technology could soon replace the equivalent of 300 million jobs in the U.S. and Europe. But the peril of losing our jobs to A.I. could be undermined by another existential risk afflicting society, says former Google CEO and executive chairman Eric Schmidt: the developed world‚Äôs rapidly declining birth rate.  ‚ÄúHere are the facts. We are not having enough children, and we have not been having enough children for long enough that there is a demographic crisis where people who are my age are going to be taken care of by younger generations,‚Äù Schmidt said at the Wall Street Journal‚Äôs CEO Council Summit in London Wednesday.  Schmidt pushed back against the ‚Äúnarrative‚Äù that new technologies are inevitably going to cause disruption and lead to widespread job loss, saying that when it comes to A.I., the net benefit will likely be positive because of enhanced efficiency and the technology‚Äôs ability to replace professions that are already getting harder to fill in a shrinking labor market.  In the U.S., a historically tight labor market could become even tighter in the coming decades as a result of fewer children being born. Aside from a pandemic-induced ‚Äúbaby bump‚Äù in 2021, U.S. fertility rates‚Äîthe number of children each woman would be expected to have in her lifetime‚Äîhas been on a mostly steady decline since the mid-2000s, including a record-breaking 4% drop in 2020.  Couples‚Äô concerns about their finances, crushing student loan and credit card debt, and a greater focus on career are some of the reasons Americans are having fewer kids (another is that in more developed countries, the birth rate seems to be lower just out of choice alone). Similar shifts are happening in developed economies in Europe and East Asia, but the trend might have serious economic consequences in the years ahead. With baby boomers retiring in higher numbers every year, the dearth of young people to replace an aging workforce could lead to a demographic and labor crisis within the next few decades.  ‚ÄúIn aggregate, all the demographics say there‚Äôs going to be a shortage of humans for jobs. Literally too many jobs and not enough people for at least the next 30 years,‚Äù Schmidt said.  Countries have proposed a number of policies to stave off the worst effects of a demographic crisis. China recently announced sweeping measures and incentives to reverse its population decline, including enhancing maternal health care services, granting 30 days of paid marriage leave in some provinces, and even discouraging abortions. Many countries are also looking overseas for workers, such as Japan‚Äîhistorically opposed to mixing up its labor force with too many foreign staff‚Äîwhich has in recent years loosened its entry requirements.  In the U.S., the population grew last year after almost flatlining in 2021, largely because of increased immigration. Several business leaders‚Äîincluding Google and Alphabet‚Äôs current CEO, India-born Sundar Pichai‚Äîhave long argued that the U.S. should welcome more migrants to fill out its labor ranks.  A.I. might also have a crucial part to play in the country‚Äôs labor force struggles, especially for jobs that workers were already walking away from during the early pandemic‚Äôs Great Resignation owing to burnout and unsafe working conditions. History shows that technology tends to automatically fill the gaps created by worker shortages. A 2021 MIT study found that aging accounted for 35% of the adoption of robots and automation in different countries. The authors also argued that fast-aging countries that also invested heavily in their robotics industries such as Germany, South Korea, and Japan were seeing better labor market outcomes than the U.S.  Companies started tapping A.I. and automation technology years ago for jobs like truck driving and bartending, professions that many workers willingly walked away from during the pandemic. However, the recent pace of A.I. growth threatens to be far more immediate and pervasive, as a March study by ChatGPT creator OpenAI found that 80% of U.S. workers could have at least 10% of their jobs impacted by A.I. The risk A.I. poses to jobs was one of the reasons OpenAI CEO Sam Altman urged Congress to regulate A.I. during his testimony earlier this month.  Schmidt argued that A.I. would eventually become a tool for efficiency in the workforce, but while it may end up as a net-positive for the labor force, job losses in the near term might be inevitable.  ‚ÄúWhat really happens is that people like yourselves, in the business community and so forth, you‚Äôre about efficiency. Ultimately there will be lots of job conflagration, right? Some jobs are created, some jobs are lost.‚Äù

The house in Austria where Nazi leader Adolf Hitler was born will be converted into a human rights training center for police officers, Austria‚Äôs Interior Ministry announced Wednesday, according to CNN.  The building in the northwestern town of Braunau am Inn will accommodate the facility along with a police station, for which the Austrian government disclosed plans in 2019.  The decision was made based on the recommendations of an interdisciplinary expert commission concerned with depriving the property of its ‚Äúmythical appeal to extremist circles,‚Äù the ministry said in a statement quoted by CNN.  The conversion ‚Äì which will cost an estimated 20 million euros ‚Äì is expected to be completed in 2025, with the police moving in the following year.  Hitler was born in an apartment in the building on April 20, 1889 and lived there until his family left when he was three years old.  The government took control of the building in December of 2016, after MPs approved an expropriation law specifically aimed at the property.  The move came after years of wrangling with the owner of the home, Gerlinde Pommer, who had been renting the house to the interior ministry since the 1970s and refused to sell it or carry out essential renovation works.  Pommer later campaigned to be compensated in full for the loss of her property. A court subsequently ordered the Austrian government to pay Pommer 1.5 million euros.  Hitler's birth home has attracted neo-Nazis and other extremists for years, with extremists making the trip to take a picture in front of the building. Glorifying the Nazi era is a crime in Austria.

Gauahar Khan , who gave birth to her first child - a baby boy - on May 10, has more than one reason to rejoice. The actress is not only enjoying the new phase of motherhood but has also managed to shed a significant amount of weight in just a few days.Taking to her Instagram stories, Gauahar shared a picture sporting comfy loungewear in earthen colour. She wrote, "Lost 10 kgs in 10 days postpartum . Alhamdulillah. 6 more to go. New mom life."Gauahar has always been somebody who has looked after herself. The actress is into yoga and practices different forms of workout.In December last year, Gauahar and her husband Zaid, who got married in 2020, announced their pregnancy. The couple's family and friends were thrilled for them and showered their blessings and love.The actress delivered a baby boy on May 10.The two shared the news on Instagram with their fans in a post which read, "It's a boy. Assalam Wulaikum beautiful world, says our bundle of joy. Arrived 10th of May, 2023 to make us realise what happiness truly means. Our blessed boy thanks everyone for their love and prayers. Grateful and giggling new parents, Zaid and Gauahar."Visuals of their leaving the hospital after delivery were also captured. The actress thanked the paps for congratulatory wishes before leaving for home.

This article has been reviewed according to Science X's editorial process and policies . Editors have highlighted the following attributes while ensuring the content's credibility:  After birth, GLA activates RXR in the postnatal cardiomyocytes. This results in the activation of genetic programs that ensure that the cardiomyocyte mitochondria mature and use lipids as the energy source for the generation of ATP. This metabolic adaptation makes sure that the myocardium is provided with enough energy to sustain the heartbeat outside the womb, thus ensuring postnatal survival. Credit: CNIC  A study conducted in mice and led by researchers at the Centro Nacional de Investigaciones Cardiovasculares (CNIC) has revealed that maternal milk provides an essential signal that triggers the maturation of heart metabolism after birth, allowing the neonatal heart to function correctly and ensuring postnatal survival.  The study shows that the fatty acid gamma-linolenic acid (GLA), present in breast milk, binds to the retinoid X receptor (RXR) protein found in heart cells. RXR acts as a nutritional sensor of lipids and vitamin A derivatives, altering gene expression and influencing biological functions such as immunity, cell differentiation, and metabolism. Once activated by maternal GLA, RXR initiates genetic programs that equip mitochondria, the energy centers of the cell, with the enzymes and other proteins they need to to start consuming lipids, the primary source of energy in the mature heart.  The results, published May 24, 2023 in Nature, could have significant therapeutic implications for cardiovascular disorders involving mitochondrial and metabolic dysfunction, as well as diseases related to alterations in postnatal developmental processes, explained study leader Dr. Mercedes Ricote, who heads the Nuclear Receptor Signaling group at the CNIC.  In a mouse model, the research team found that the absence of RXR in the heart or the lack of GLA in maternal milk prevented mitochondria in the hearts of newborn mice from producing energy correctly, leading to severe heart failure and death 24 to 48 hours after birth.  The heart of a newborn mammal must quickly produce energy to sustain cardiac contraction outside of the womb. To achieve this, cardiomyocytes, the contracting cells of the myocardium (the cardiac muscle), need to activate their mitochondria to use lipids as the energy source for the generation of ATP (adenosine triphosphate‚Äîthe essential energy currency of the cell). Although this process is crucial for the survival of the organism, until now, little was known about the signals that trigger the physiological adaptation of the heart after birth.  "The need to maintain a constant and uninterrupted beat places an immense energy demand on the heart," explained Dr. Ricote. "To meet their energy needs, cardiomyocytes maintain a tight control over the cellular pathways that produce energy. Any imbalance in these bioenergetic mechanisms can lead to the development of serious cardiovascular pathologies."  For Dr. Ricote, part of the study's novelty "lies in demonstrating that RXR plays a critical role in cardiac muscle, contrary to what was previously thought. This is an important conceptual advance in the field of nuclear receptors."  According to first author Dr. Ana Paredes, the study presents a new framework for understanding the postnatal adaptations that occur in newborn mammals to meet the requirements of the extrauterine environment. "Birth is a physiological challenge for the newborn," Dr. Paredes explained. "With this study, we show that maternal milk, besides its nutritional function, plays a signaling role by instructing cardiomyocytes that they need to activate their metabolism because they are no longer supported by maternal physiology."  In conclusion, the study shows that the fatty acid GLA, found in breast milk, is the key signal that ensures correct cardiac function after birth. GLA activates the cell protein RXR, which then directs coordinated gene expression changes to ensure that cardiomyocyte mitochondria mature so that they can produce energy in the extrauterine environment.  The results open the way to treatments to modulate RXR activity in cardiomyocytes with specific drugs, including some that already have approval from the US Federal Drug Administration for cancer treatments. "Our study proposes RXR as a possible therapeutic target for neonatal heart disorders and systemic diseases triggered by metabolic errors," concluded Dr. Ricote.  The research involved multidisciplinary approaches and advanced sequencing techniques, including key contributions from the CNIC teams led by Dr. Jos√© Antonio Enr√≠quez, Dr. F√°tima S√°nchez-Cabo, and Dr. Jes√∫s V√°zquez.  More information: Mercedes Ricote, Œ≥-Linolenic acid in maternal milk drives cardiac metabolic maturation, Nature (2023). DOI: 10.1038/s41586-023-06068-7. www.nature.com/articles/s41586-023-06068-7 Journal information: Nature  Provided by Centro Nacional de Investigaciones Cardiovasculares Carlos III (F.S.P.)

The 11-digit birth number (rodn√© ƒç√≠slo) is used by Czech citizens and residents for filing taxes, banking, insurance, and similar purposes. The system, which dates back to 1954, uses a person‚Äôs date of birth and gender as a basis. The first two digits indicate the last two digits of the year of birth, the second two digits indicate the month of birth, which is increased by 50 for women, and the third two digits indicate the day of birth. A four-digit ending distinguishes people born on the same day.

Get ready to let out a loud, "Awwwwww," next time you make a trip to Evansville's Mesker Park Zoo & Botanic Garden.  Officials with the zoo made an exciting announcement on Facebook Tuesday afternoon saying its two howler monkeys, Ulick and Callie, welcomed a new bundle of joy over the weekend, making it the first-ever baby howler monkey born at the zoo.  Get our free mobile app  Mesker Park Zoo & Botanic Garden Mesker Park Zoo & Botanic Garden loading...  The proud parents Callie (female, left) and Ulick (male, right).  Native to Central and South America, howler monkeys are known for their loud voices. Callie, Ulick, and their new baby live in the Amazonia exhibit at Mesker Park Zoo as it best mimics their natural habitat. Chances are, if you've ever walked through the exhibit you've likely heard one of them calling out to the other, or just showing off their impressive pipes. If you've not been through the exhibit, this is what a howler monkey sounds like:  Congratulations! It's a _____  According to the post on Facebook, the staff at the zoon don't know the gender of the new arrival just yet. They say they'll have to wait until the baby feels comfortable enough to explore their habitat on their own. For now, it's most comfortable clinging as tightly as it can to its momma, regardless of whether she taking a stroll along the treetops or just trying to eat (something all human mothers can definitely relate to).  Mesker Park Zoo & Botanic Garden Mesker Park Zoo & Botanic Garden loading...  Mesker Park Zoo & Botanic Garden Mesker Park Zoo & Botanic Garden loading...  The good news is, unlike the baby penguin born a few weeks ago who is being kept behind the scenes until it is big enough to join the rest of its fellow penguins in the Penguins of Patagonia exhibit, the baby howler is already out and about with mom and dad and can be seen by visitors. Of course, it might be a little hard to spot while it's clinging to Mom.  READ MORE: Mesker Park Zoo Welcomes Adorable Baby Penguin into the World!  Visit the Mesker Park Zoo website for regular hours and admission prices.  [Source: Mesker Park Zoo & Botanic Garden on Facebook]

It‚Äôs date night in Miami!  Derek Jeter and his wife Hannah attended Game 4 of the NBA‚Äôs Eastern Conference finals between the Boston Celtics and Miami Heat Tuesday night, just weeks after the couple welcomed their newborn son.  The couple was spotted sitting courtside at Kaseya Center in Miami when the cameras panned on the former Yankees icon and partner sitting by each other‚Äôs sides.  Jeter sported a plain white-colored button-down shirt with dark-blue jeans, while his model wife Hannah wore a black t-shirt and light-blue jeans.  One familiar face at the game was Jeter‚Äôs former Yankees teammate, Alex Rodriguez, who sat next to Minnesota Timberwolves star Anthony Edwards.  Other notable celebs in attendance to watch the Celtics avoid a sweep with their 116-99 win over the Heat were Ivanka Trump, PGA Champion Brooks Koepka, and actor Jeremy Piven.  Jeter surprised the world on May 8 when he announced that he and Hannah welcomed their fourth child together, son Kaius Green Jeter.  He announced Kaius was born on May 5.  ‚ÄúWelcome to the world lil man!!‚Äù Jeter captioned the post.  Derek and Hannah Jeter are spotted sitting court-side next to each other at Kaseya Center in Miami on May 23, 2023. NBAE via Getty Images  The legendary Yankees infielder and his wife Hannah, known for her appearances in the Sports Illustrated Swimsuit Issue, tied the knot in July of 2016 after being engaged for nearly a year.  Together they share daughters Bella Raine, 5, Story Grey, 4, River Rose, 1, and newborn son Kaius.  Fans on Twitter had a field day with posts about Jeter and A-Rod both attending the game.  Derek Jeter is seen sporting a plain white-colored button-down shirt with dark-blue jeans during the Miami Heat and Boston Celtics game at Kaseya Center in Miami on May 23, 2023. NBAE via Getty Images  ‚ÄúIf I were a Miami Heat fan, not sure I would have allowed Jeter & A-Rod in the building up 3-0,‚Äù one person joked.  ‚ÄúDerek jeter and a-rod cursing the heat with their presence at game 4 while the Celtics go on to win the finals is my all-time favorite NBA storyline,‚Äù another user jokingly posted.  Jeter stepped away from his role as CEO of the Miami Marlins in 2022 and will serve as an MLB analyst for Fox Sports.  He will be teamed on the set with Rodriguez and Red Sox legend David Ortiz for special events throughout the season, including the 2023 MLB London Series on June 24 ‚Äî where he will make his debut and the MLB All-Star Game, the network announced.

On 14th May we commemorated the birth centenary of film maker Mrinal Sen. Mrinal Sen was the last surviving member of the famed trio of Bengali directors, Ray-Sen-Ghatak (Ritwik Ghatak), seen as the founders of India‚Äôs ‚ÄòNew Wave Cinema‚Äô. Sen, like Ghatak, may not have achieved the level of fame Ray did, but his work was equally admired the world over. Together they enriched the international reputation for the country which no other filmmakers had been able to.  Mrinal Sen was neither versatile like Satyajit Ray nor were his films painted with the pathos of our partition like the cinema of Ritwik Ghatak. Yet the maestro had his own benchmarks in comparison to his illustrious competitors. He devised a style of film making never seen before, making path breaking experiments.  A socialist by ideology, Mrinal Sen tapped into Bengal‚Äôs political psyche and created celluloid images of a reality in realms many would not dare to project.  The manner he dissected scenes, integrated characters or constructed dialogues had touches of genius.  In the manner of Bertolt Brecht, he made an audience detached, think for themselves, and not get swept away by emotion.  In a most subtle manner he manifested class antagonism and how social conditions shaped people‚Äôs lives.  In chronicling political dissent he hardly had an equal.  An avid reader of Karl Marx, Frederick Angeles, Rabindranath Tagore and Munshi Premchand, Mrinal Sen was always donned the qualities of a down-to-earth and affectionate person .  Mrinal Sen resented the authority of the Communist party or orthodox party structure.  Sen‚Äôs greatest attribute was his courage to question himself at the very root, which is a rare phenomenon amongst great artists.  Mrinal Sen was shaken to the ground with the collapse of USSR and East European countries, making him turn inwards.  Paying a tribute to Mrinal Sen on his birth centenary year, national award-winning director Kaushik Ganguly, in his next venture ‚ÄòPalan‚Äô, is recreating the characters of the master filmmaker‚Äôs critically acclaimed ‚ÄòKharij‚Äô.  Background and Early Life  Born into a middle-class family from Faridpur (now in Bangladesh) in undivided India, he witnessed the freedom struggle and the communist movement from close quarters, and even courted arrest.  Sen upheld communist ideology throughout his life (according to him, he was a private Marxist). A Marxist, Mrinal Sen was closely associated with the Indian People‚Äôs Theatre Association (IPTA) between 1943-47, though never a member of the Communist Party. He made films that most vividly or lucidly illustrated Indian society ‚Äì in diverse Indian languages. He made films in Bengali, Hindi, Oriya, and Telugu.  His interest in films was cultivated late and only after he began reading about them. According to an interview of his in the American film magazine Cineaste, occasionally he would get a few copies of foreign cinema journals where he first discovered the Italian neorealist movement. During this time, he did a variety of odd jobs. He worked at a print shop, became a medical representative, an instructor at a private institution, and an audio technician in a Calcutta film studio.  Film Career  It was not a smooth riding for Mrinal Sen in his film career. His directorial debut, Raat Bhor starring Uttam Kumar was rejected. Though Neel Akasher Niche and Baishe Sraban earned him popularity, he became an international legend with Bhuvan Some.  Goutam Ghose says that Mrinal Sen was compelled to write scripts for directors like Ajay Kar‚Äôs Kanch Kata Heera. He also wrote Jora Dighir Chowdhuryr Paribar to enable him to earn a decent living till he became famous with his Calcutta Trilogy and then there was no looking back for him.  His film Neel Akasher Neechey (1959) ‚Äì set in the 1930s and exploring both anti-colonial nationalism and the class divide in Indian society ‚Äì was the first film ever to be banned in independent India. The film shook India‚Äôs first Government because it illustrated the absolute apathy of India‚Äôs elites towards its poor and disadvantaged people, even though both inhabited the same soil. The ban was lifted after three months ‚Äì but was an early sign of the Indian State‚Äôs intolerance to dissent.  Govind Nihalani was enamoured with the use of freeze and zoom shots in Mrinal Sen‚Äôs Akash Kusum.(1965) t is the story of the dreams of a middle class executive to gain greater stature and greater social acceptability. The young man attempting to secure a footing in the corporate world disguises himself till his deception turns disastrous for him, and ruins their relationship.  He made his first flash in Hindi cinema with Bhuvan Shome (1969).The legendary Uttpal Dutt portrayed the role of a westernized railway officer who unravels there is a life beyond the boundaries of bureaucracy during his duck hunting trip to Gujarat. Suhasini Mulay as a young tribal woman helps Dutt to untap the ordinary joys of life. The negativity of a feudal society that begins stagnating is brilliantly synthesised in Bhavan Some.  He brilliantly delved into the themes of 1970s India in many films. Sen‚Äôs Interview, Calcutta 71 (1971) and Padatik (1973) delved in exploring the social and political upheavals in the city during the turbulent naxalbari uprising, and are thematic portrayals of the politics of The Naxalite Movement. In a most subtle manner he illustrated the impact of the naxalite movement in shaping the lives of people  Interview (1971) follows a young man who is disqualified from a job because he lacks a suit to wear. A pathbreaking film. Although based on the colonial hangover, it reflected a wide range of issues like anti-establishment, middle class cowardice, and unemployment.  Calcutta 71 (1972) reveals the dehumanising aspects of deprivation and poverty on the one hand, and hypocrisy of affluence on the other, culminating with a young Naxalite being killed in cold blood by the police. It narrates the violence and corruption throughout the course of history. Scene dissection simply outstanding. A most lucid and illustrative study of the political turmoil of the seventies, documenting the agony of the common people taking intensity to heights rarely reached in Indian cinema. Here restlessness was captured at it‚Äôs absolute pitch.  The jump cuts of Calcutta 71 entangled with mime acting in certain scenes was a model in direction.  Padatik (1973) examined the contradictions or dichtonomy between middle class values and a young Naxalite revolutionary with the narrative conveyed with cinematic artistry in realms untouched. In ‚ÄòPadatik‚Äô we witness the scenario of Kolkata as in the early 1970s; a place brimming with chaos.. Mrinal Sen portrays the burning issues within the scenario of political turmoil, with great sensitivity. The narrative follows a young political activist (Dhritiman Chatterjee) who escapes a prison van and takes shelter in a posh apartment owned by a sensitive young woman (Simi Garewal).Dialogues and scenes carved touching reality at the very rock bottom, with no element of melodrama, giving a viewer a great insight into the political scenario and how its shaped people‚Äôs lives.  Mrigayaa (1976) is set in the background of the Santhal rebellion and colonial rule which unfolded the double standards of the colonial state, which rewarded ‚Äòhunting down‚Äô revolutionaries and wild animals ‚Äì but punished the killing of oppressors. Those features of the colonial state are ressurected by the Indian State today ‚Äì and that is what makes the film relevant even in today‚Äôs India. Mrigaaya‚Äô featured Mithun Chakraborty as a tribal man who is reputed to be one of the best hunters around, even by the British rulers. Yet t he was hanged after being found guilty of murdering the moneylender who kidnapped his wife. His trial and death later spark rebellion among the tribal people.  Ek Din Pratidin (1979) superbly manifests middle class patriarchy in India which circumscribes women‚Äôs autonomy even as it needs women to earn. This was reflected in a family‚Äôs response when their young daughter who is also the main breadwinner fails to return home one night ‚Äì and then returns the next morning. It ridicules conventional morality.  Akaler Sandhane (1982), with untold mastery , captures how a film unit in a village is trying to capture the pulse of the Bengal famine of 1943 & finds no difference between then and now; or between reel life and real life, The film unravels s the convivial life among the film crew and the hurdles of filmmaking on location. It bridges the link between 1943 and 1980, in the manner of past meeting the present.  Khandhar (1984) written by Premendra Mitra, penetrates the flurry of emotions within the human mind when it is faced with a choice between the revolutionary and difficult, and the ordinary but comfortable. Subash (Naseeruddin Shah), an eager but not-so-well established photographer visits a cast-off village which is in ruins along with his two friends. On the first night of his venture, he notices a girl. The following day, he gets to know that the girl, Jamini (Shabana Azmi), continued to live in the ruins with her dying mother after the village was abandoned by the Zamindars due to a malaria epidemic many decades ago. Scene dissection and direction epitomising artistry at it‚Äôs very best.  Jamini represents a conventional Indian maiden on the surface, yet aspires for her circumstances to change. She is an insecure, dutiful daughter who sometimes expresses her indignation of being alone and betrayed by her mother but recognizes her ‚Äòfault‚Äô the very next moment and rapidly returns to abiding to the task of of a caring but mournful daughter. Subash gets drawn to this sensitive and civilized girl, which crystallises the theme. One is left in suspense if history will repeat itself for Subash and Jamini.  Mahaprithivi‚Äô (1991) begins with the sequence of suicide of a mother one of whose sons, at the helm of the Naxalite movement two decades earlier, was shot dead by the police. It examines the reasons behind her taking this step and whether with communism collapsing in country after country, her son‚Äôs sacrifice would be dumped into the dustbin of history.  Mrinal Sen won awards at Cannes and also served as a jury member in the Mecca of film festivals. He termed Cannes his second home. During his lifetime he cherished recollected his interactions with Akira Kurasawa, Richard Attenborough and Jean Luc Goddard. He attributed how Goddard shaped his filmmaking style.  He won special jury prizes for Akaler Shandhaney (In Search of Famine, 1981) at Berlin and Kharij (The Case Is Closed, 1982) at Cannes.  Characteristics of Mrinal Sen‚Äôs films  First, he had the courage to make films which were staunchly political. His ‚ÄòCalcutta Trilogy‚Äô and ‚ÄòChorus‚Äô, for instance, were landmarks. Renowned critic Derek Malcolm wrote, ‚Äú‚Ä¶ but against tremendous odds, he has traced the social and political ferment of India with greater resilience and audacity than any other contemporary Indian director‚Ä¶‚Äù  Second, Sen refrained from being stereotyped. Two of his popular films ‚Äî ‚ÄòNeel Akasher Niche‚Äô (1958), and the influential ‚ÄòBhuvan Shome‚Äô pioneered the Indian new wave and Sen illustrated untold mastery over the narrative format. However, instead of continuing that way, he altered his conventional format through bolder films that followed.  Third, he not only explored the middle and lower-middle class realities but was brave enough to question himself too. He quoted physicist Niels Bohr: ‚ÄúConfidence comes from not being always right, but from not fearing to be wrong.‚Äù This attitude, of never afraid of making a mistake, sparkled his creativity and sustained his spirit.  Flaws  It is regretful that Mrinal Sen ventured into personalised films after being disillusioned with the fall of Communism, from the 1990‚Äôs. In later periods, he did not embark on the task of documenting films s confronting the anti-Communist propaganda or the tormentation of people with the advent of globalisation.  Harsh Thakor is freelance journalist who has done extensive research on film makers.Owes gratitude for information on Mrinal Sen from sources like The Tribune, The Hindu, India Times and Interview of Shabana Azmi
The birth rate is closely interwoven with the total fertility rate, which further tracks the average number of children that women in a given country give birth to during their childbearing years.

Experts say that 2 million more Italians will have retired with no one to replace them or pay their pensions in only seven more years, 2030.  What can God do in your life with one Bible verse a day? Subscribe to Aleteia's new service and bring Scripture into your morning:  Just one verse each day. Click to bring God's word to your inbox  Pope Francis was in attendance for the recent ‚ÄúGeneral States of Natality,‚Äù an Italian conference that seeks to address the ongoing crisis of low birth rates, often described as a ‚Äúdemographic winter.‚Äù The Pope noted a variety of social and economic factors that have contributed to the declining Italian birth rates, stating, ‚ÄúThe family is not part of the problem, but is part of its solution.‚Äù  At a 2021 Angelus address, the Pontiff lamented that, in Italy, ‚ÄúIt seems that many couples prefer not to have children or to have only one child.‚Äù  A report from CNN, however, is suggesting that the desire to have many children exists in Italian parents, but there are several hurdles that make it difficult.  Aleteia has previously reported on the dwindling birth rates of Italy:  According to The World Factbook, with only 1.24 births per woman, Italy has the worst fertility rate in Europe and the 6th worst globally. The 2023 birth rate in the country was 7 births per 1,000 people, and Italian women tend to have children on average at around 31 years old. There were 392,598 births in 2022, 7,651 fewer than in 2021 (-1.9%).  The Italian birth rate has been consistently falling since the 2008 economic crisis and the continuing trend is largely being blamed on the economic instability that persists in a large portion of the population. CNN took a look at the economy in relation to the falling birth rates to explain the fall of Italian fertility.  Examining monthly income of prospective parents, CNN found that the average monthly earnings in Italy stands at ‚Ç¨2,475 a month, according to figures from ISTAT. With the average cost of a 100-square-meter (1,000-square-foot) apartment being ‚Ç¨1,212, the report quickly identified the housing market as a prime factor of financial struggles. Prospective parents who are spending half their monthly pay just to keep a roof over their heads may take pause when considering adding another member to the family.  Monthly savings were also found to have fallen drastically since the 2020 pandemic. Whereas Italy was once considered a nation of ‚Äúsavers,‚Äù with the average family putting aside 20% of their monthly income, now this figure has fallen to just over 5% as of 2023. The report notes that the Italian government offers incentives for parents to have more children, including a monthly grant of ‚Ç¨175 per child, but CNN pointed towards similar tactics that have not borne fruit in Germany or France.  CNN spoke with a young married couple ‚Äì Claudia Giagheddu Saitta, 27, and Gabriele De Luca, 31 ‚Äì who have been hesitant to start their family in the current economic climate. Claudia said that monthly grants and tax cuts on baby products are not enough to put them at ease:  ‚ÄúThe government thinks ‚Ç¨10,000 ($10,800) is enough to have a child. But the incentives are temporary. A child lasts forever,‚Äù Giagheddu Saitta says. She says the idea of having more than one child, if she has one at all, feels impossible.  De Luca went on to blame the government for not doing enough to support an incoming younger generation. He said that the government was voted in by those in their 50s to 70s, who place their own interests before those of the next generation. Furthermore, he suggested that Italy may need to take some risks in displeasing this voter base if it wishes to spur a baby boom.  While the largest voter base in Italy continues to be those at or approaching retirement age, the lackluster fertility rates should be of concern to them as well. Italy‚Äôs pension system is described as ‚Äúpay-as-you-go,‚Äù in which the current workforce pays into the pension program to support those who have retired. This fund, however, is placed in jeopardy by low levels of new workers entering the workforce. It is thought that by 2030, 2 million workers will have entered retirement with no new members of the workforce to pay their pensions.  Read more at CNN.

Approved since 2015 in the United Kingdom, research on the Mitochondrial Replacement Technology (MRT), presented as a treatment by donation of mitochondria, is being carried out by the Newcastle Fertility Center.  As early as 2018, the British Reproduction and Embryology Authority (HFEA) approved the first in vitro fertilization trials using this technique. It is a process which, while not treating the disease from which the mother is suffering, is not without risk for the child either.  Mitochondria are micro-organelles present in almost all human cells and which generate most of a cell's energy. They are mainly provided by the oocyte during fertilization and are therefore essentially of maternal origin.  Sometimes mitochondria have genetic abnormalities that cause serious and incurable medical conditions. To prevent a mother whose mitochondria are failing from transmitting this anomaly to her child, the mother's mitochondria are replaced with mitochondria from a donor.  Until now, women with defective mitochondria could appeal for egg donation. With the donation of mitochondria, the embryos carry the DNA of the biological father, the DNA of the biological mother and the mitochondrial DNA of the donor (which represents approximately 37 genes).  To date, there is no guarantee that the child thus conceived is actually free from the disease of which its mother is a carrier. Interviewed by The Guardian, genetics professor Dagan Wells of the University of Oxford admits that, while clinical experiences of the mitochondrial transfer technique are encouraging, the number of cases remains too low to be sure of the safety and the effectiveness of the technique.  Mitochondria can indeed remain attached to the nucleus of the egg at the time of nuclear transfer, multiply or even take over compared to healthy mitochondria. This involves selecting in vitro the embryo that will have a rate of abnormal mitochondria of less than 10%, but also verifying the absence of a ‚Äúturnaround‚Äù during pregnancy by means of prenatal tests.  This technique presents two moral transgressions at two different levels. The first is that of in vitro fertilization in general, which is reprehensible for many reasons: the immoral obtaining of male gametes in the first place, and second, all the consequences such as the multiple destruction of embryos which mark the history of this technique.  The second transgression is specific to this technique: from in vitro fertilization to prenatal testing, without forgetting embryonic selection, the technique of mitochondrial transfer is punctuated by manipulations that are currently still uncertain and which question ethics from the point of view of dignity, of the genetic heritage and the health of these children who are the subjects of experimentation.  There are now many works on epigenetics which have shown that the various manipulations that accompany and surround in vitro fertilization are responsible for various genetic diseases. The full list is still being compiled.
